ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: How to read advanced Japanese such as essays and articles, discuss their topics, give speeches in Japanese, etc

This course developed my Japanese writing, reading, and discussion skills. By having a lot of time in class dedicated to discussion, I really felt like I progressed in being able to express my ideas and opinions more clearly.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Given the challenges of teaching people with very different backgrounds in Japanese, I think the course was very well done and the material we covered was helpful and my Japanese definitely improved. If there was some way to individualize it even further that would be best, but I'm not sure that's possible.

I enjoyed that the students in the course ranged widely in age and program. It gave us a lot to learn about from each other and made every conversation interesting! I only disliked that the format of each class meeting was largely the same, which grew a bit tiresome toward the end of the semester. I would say the course could improve by shaking up the pattern of whole group discussion - break out rooms - whole group discussion.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Using zoom breakout rooms for discussion worked well. I don't think there are any improvements that need to be made, though in-person will always be better for language classes I think.

I'm glad that the instructor regularly used breakout rooms of 2-3 because it facilitated more speaking in Japanese, but after a while I found myself tired of the breakout rooms and would have preferred another way of engaging in discussion.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes. While studying abroad is still the only way to seriously improve your Japanese at this level, if you don't have that opportunity (or just want to maximize your time spent studying Japanese at Yale like I did), there's still enough to gain from this course that it's worthwhile.
One of the benefits of Yale is the ability to take Japanese at an advanced level, so yes I would recommend the course.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
